messages.title: HARD WORKING FAMILIES LOSE OUT UNDER TORIES
messages.content: Over the last year hard working families in Swindon have needed support to help them through the effects of the recession. The cut in interest rates has helped thousands of people with mortgage bills, £5billion of extra support has helped people back to work and Labour guaranteed all 16-18 year olds a place at college or training, to prevent them from being a lost generation.

messages.title: UNDER THE TORIES
messages.content: The losers: Average families earning £31,000 could lose Child Tax Credit and the Child Trust Fund. The winners: Millionaires stand to gain a £200,000 inheritance tax cut.

messages.title: Crime Falls Again in Swindon
messages.content: Crime fell by 20% across Swindon compared to last year meaning that our town is safer. Since 1997 crime has fallen by 36% across the country. Despite the recession crime fell again meaning that you are less likely to be a victim of crime. During the 1990s Tory recession burglary, robbery and theft rose by 19% in 1990 and 18% in 1991.

keyPolicies.policyDescription: Support through the recession with lower interest rates and financial aid for families.
Guaranteed place at college or training for all 16-18 year olds.
Effective policing leading to reduced crime in Swindon, and efforts to combat crime nationally since 1997.

issues.economy: The leaflet discusses support for families during the recession and impact on average families' finances under Conservative policies.
issues.education: Guaranteed education and training opportunities for 16-18 year olds mentioned.
issues.socialWelfare: Mentions of financial support for families and concerns about Conservative cuts to Child Tax Credit and Child Trust Fund.

endorsements.endorsement: "We went to Anne, she got our problem sorted quickly, thanks Anne."

images.caption: Anne Snelgrove in discussion with constituents
